history.content:
I think the only weakness that might hurt you is the CPU/circuits stuff. If you want to go into anything hardware-related you'll have to get much better at that. All the rest (like advanced RISC), they're good to know but I don't feel like they're used much in industry.

The most relevant topics for SWE would probably be C and parallelism. (I was recently asked in an interview about thread synchronization which is kinda related to parallelism - data races, things like that.)

If someone is going into Software Engineering as a profession, for Full Stack, Mobile, or ML..

Which topics from 61C are useful to master? http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs61c/fa18/

I'm very knowledgable(in context of the course) in: Number Rep, Everything C related, Very Basic RISCV code, Everything Caches, Parallelism, Conceptual understanding of Pipelining, I/O, Virtual Memory, and a bit of Combinational Logic. But i'm really bad at Advanced RISCV, Floating Point Calculations, Anything CPU related and designing circuits using Logism, and the little details of compilation of code.

I guess I feel bad i'm not really good at certain topics in this course and don't want the lack of knowledge to hinder my career.
history.subject: 61c Topics Useful For Software Engineering?
